feed.title: Security Advisory for PHP packages hosted at packagist.org
feed.subtitle: Security Advisory for PHP packages hosted at packagist.org on GitHub

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Information Disclosure in Page Tree
entry.content:
It has been discovered backend users not having read access to specific pages still could see them in the page tree which actually should be disallowed. A valid backend user account is needed in order to exploit this vulnerability.

References

  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-05-07-4.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-009
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-wvvp-jwf5-qcpc

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Security Misconfiguration in User Session Handling
entry.content:
When users change their password existing sessions for that particular user account are not revoked. A valid backend or frontend user account is required in order to make use of this vulnerability.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/437bf78c0ef64a059c7feaa5164f6f028507b425
  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/e21f0e5d29b68a7e64448762b3f86ac24d36627f
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-05-07-2.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-011
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-xmgr-jff3-fcfv

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Security Misconfiguration in User Session Handling

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Cross-Site Scripting in Form Framework
entry.content:
Failing to properly encode user input, frontend forms handled by the form framework (system extension “form”) are vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/3b8b8b4416b921df4ccc7c5b4a8e9a069562be35
  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/a0e917008320e24c26780ba385fbfe738fcd45b9
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-6.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-007
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-4459-qrcc-vfcf

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Cross-Site Scripting in Form Framework
entry.content:
Failing to properly encode user input, frontend forms handled by the form framework (system extension “form”) are vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/3b8b8b4416b921df4ccc7c5b4a8e9a069562be35

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Cross-Site Scripting in Language Pack Handling
entry.content:
Failing to properly encode information from external sources, language pack handling in the install tool is vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

References

  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-8.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-004
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-76r3-m635-p3vc

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Arbitrary Code Execution via File List Module
entry.content:
Due to missing file extensions in $GLOBALS['TYPO3_CONF_VARS']['BE'][‘fileDenyPattern’], backend users are allowed to upload *.phar, *.shtml, *.pl or *.cgi files which can be executed in certain web server setups. A valid backend user account is needed in order to exploit this vulnerability.

Derivatives of Debian GNU Linux are handling *.phar files as PHP applications since PHP 7.1 (for unofficial packages) and PHP 7.2 (for official packages).

The file extension *.shtml is bound to server side includes which are not enabled per default in most common Linux based distributions. File extension *.pl and *.cgi require additional handlers to be configured which is also not the case in most common distributions (except for /cgi-bin/ location).

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/45c311d120c359d54cc918e962c374e774239899
  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/5095084efae471c5fef7b578f2bc8a5060e1e148
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-7.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-008
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-f9hr-7cfq-mjg2

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Arbitrary Code Execution via File List Module

Due to missing file extensions in $GLOBALS['TYPO3_CONF_VARS']['BE'][‘fileDenyPattern’], backend users are allowed to upload *.phar, *.shtml, *.pl or *.cgi files which can be executed in certain web server setups. A valid backend user account is needed in order to exploit this vulnerability.

Derivatives of Debian GNU Linux are handling *.phar files as PHP applications since PHP 7.1 (for unofficial packages) and PHP 7.2 (for official packages).

The file extension *.shtml is bound to server side includes which are not enabled per default in most common Linux based distributions. File extension *.pl and *.cgi require additional handlers to be configured which is also not the case in most common distributions (except for /cgi-bin/ location).

  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-f9hr-7cfq-mjg2

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Broken Access Control in Localization Handling
entry.content:
It has been discovered that backend users having limited access to specific languages are capable of modifying and creating pages in the default language which actually should be disallowed. A valid backend user account is needed in order to exploit this vulnerability.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/64b1b5dc2f7cacb2ba39b74081f4179d6393b2bf
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-3.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-003
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-9rx9-7fmh-gj3g

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Cross-Site Scripting in Fluid ViewHelpers
entry.content:
Failing to properly encode user input, templates using built-in Fluid ViewHelpers are vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

References

  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-4.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-005
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-22q7-cg4r-p9mx

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Cross-Site Scripting in Fluid ViewHelpers
entry.content:
Failing to properly encode user input, templates using built-in Fluid ViewHelpers are vulnerable to cross-site scripting.

References

  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-4.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-005
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-22q7-cg4r-p9mx

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Security Misconfiguration for Backend User Accounts
entry.content:
When using the TYPO3 backend in order to create new backend user accounts, database records containing insecure or empty credentials might be persisted. When the type of user account is changed - which might be entity type or the admin flag for backend users - the backend form is reloaded in order to reflect changed configuration possibilities. However, this leads to persisting the current state as well, which can result into some of the following:

  • account contains empty login credentials (username and/or password)
  • account is incomplete and contains weak credentials (username and/or password)

Albeit the functionality provided by the TYPO3 core cannot be used either with empty usernames or empty passwords, it still can be a severe vulnerability to custom authentication service implementations.

This weakness cannot be directly exploited and requires interaction on purpose by some backend user having according privileges.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/1e0c7a60be0f324e77cdbc2dadef46458e191d47
  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/88c53ed5006c830d8da3c3a5f3c1b81839f1efb4
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2019-01-22-2.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2019-002
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rxc9-f2x6-qh4w

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Security Misconfiguration for Backend User Accounts
entry.content:
When using the TYPO3 backend in order to create new backend user accounts, database records containing insecure or empty credentials might be persisted. When the type of user account is changed - which might be entity type or the admin flag for backend users - the backend form is reloaded in order to reflect changed configuration possibilities. However, this leads to persisting the current state as well, which can result into some of the following:

  • account contains empty login credentials (username and/or password)
  • account is incomplete and contains weak credentials (username and/or password)

Albeit the functionality provided by the TYPO3 core cannot be used either with empty usernames or empty passwords, it still can be a severe vulnerability to custom authentication service implementations.

This weakness cannot be directly exploited and requires interaction on purpose by some backend user having according privileges.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/1e0c7a60be0f324e77cdbc2dadef46458e191d47

  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rxc9-f2x6-qh4w

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Denial of Service in Frontend Record Registration
entry.content:
TYPO3’s built-in record registration functionality (aka “basic shopping cart”) using recs URL parameters is vulnerable to denial of service. Failing to properly ensure that anonymous user sessions are valid, attackers can use this vulnerability in order to create an arbitrary amount of individual session-data records in the database.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/5a44f93e9233e8f72159f9a67db26ed4bd5a10e0
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2018-12-11-7.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2018-012
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-hjx5-v9xg-7h25

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Denial of Service in Frontend Record Registration
entry.content:
TYPO3’s built-in record registration functionality (aka “basic shopping cart”) using recs URL parameters is vulnerable to denial of service. Failing to properly ensure that anonymous user sessions are valid, attackers can use this vulnerability in order to create an arbitrary amount of individual session-data records in the database.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/5a44f93e9233e8f72159f9a67db26ed4bd5a10e0
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2018-12-11-7.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2018-012
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-hjx5-v9xg-7h25

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Denial of Service in Online Media Asset Handling
entry.content:
Online Media Asset Handling (*.youtube and *.vimeo files) in the TYPO3 backend is vulnerable to denial of service. Putting large files with according file extensions results in high consumption of system resources. This can lead to exceeding limits of the current PHP process which results in a dysfunctional backend component. A valid backend user account or write access on the server system (e.g. SFTP) is needed in order to exploit this vulnerability.

References

  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/9b2ecd2a402a76e17b78f78ed2ac9b7fff36d201
  • https://github.com/TYPO3-CMS/core/commit/aa2dcb340bc7f2b815c8eee02cf54e100f82f3e7
  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2018-12-11-6.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2018-011
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-29m4-mx89-3mjg

entry.title: [typo3/cms-core] TYPO3 Information Disclosure in Install Tool
entry.content:
The Install Tool exposes the current TYPO3 version number to non-authenticated users.

References

  • https://github.com/FriendsOfPHP/security-advisories/blob/master/typo3/cms-core/2018-12-11-5.yaml
  • https://typo3.org/security/advisory/typo3-core-sa-2018-010
  • https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-66c2-7g4p-wx4p
